entry.title: Read audit report for potential mass breach
entry.content: From an audit team at a client I got the following request: How do we audit the situation that RBP was incorrectly configured opening the system up for all employees potentially seeing data for colleagues that they should not have access to (e.g., see salary information). The read audit report only allows for 10 employees to be checked per run. It is not an option to run the report hundreds or even thousands of times to verify nobody actually accessed data they should not be allowed to see.

entry.title: Re: Consume Odata V2 ord V4 in custom App Fiori deployed...
entry.content:
Hello @peppez88 

Custom Fiori applications deployed on-stack in S/4HANA Public Cloud are permitted to perform CRUD operations exclusively on proprietary custom services, and not on standard API_* services.

You can‚Äôt use standard API_* services in an on-stack custom UI (Public Cloud).
SAP KBA 3445942 states deployment is blocked, citing Note 3424818 for restriction. Use API_* only from BTP side-by-side, not from UI in S/4HANA Cloud. SAP Support Portal-3445942 - UI Development in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Frequently Asked Questions

What you can use for CRUD in an on-stack customised Fiori app:

Key-User path: The Custom Business Object (CBO), along with its generated OData service (service generation can be enabled in the CBO application), is available for custom UIs deployed to the S/4HANA Cloud tenant. SAP Help Portal-Creating Custom Business Objects

Developer path (ABAP Cloud/RAP): A RAP business service (OData V4) is available in the development tenant; custom UIs can access this service and be deployed on-stack.SAP Help Portal-Developer Extensibility

If you need to interact with standard business API_BUSINESS_PARTNER or API_PRODUCT_SRV using CRUD operations:

Develop the UI alongside SAP BTP and access the published S/4 APIs using a Destination or Communication Arrangement. According to the FAQ above, this is the approved method. SAP Support Portal-3445942 - UI Development in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition - Frequently Asked Questions

SAP Useful documentation

Develop a custom UI on CBO service and deploy to S/4HANA Cloud (tutorial). SAP Develop a Custom UI for an SAP S/4HANA Cloud System

Custom Business Objects app (create BO ‚Üí generate service/UI). SAP Help Portal-Custom Business Objects

Developer Extensibility overview (RAP services for on-stack UIs). SAP Help Portal-Developer Extensibility

Chuma Ofole

entry.title: Re: XML field ustrd different
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Ustrd is usually fulfilled with the note to payee. If you are using note to payee, on SSCUI 101972 "Set Up Payment Methods for Each Country/Region for Payment Transactions" you can see which note to payee your payment is assigned to Payment Method.

Then, on SSCUI 102655 "Adjust Note to Payee" you can check how the note to payee is being fulfilled.

If you need further information, you can also review this KBA below which explain further the note to payee process and scenario according to your configuration:

  • 0003090392 - Payment advice and note to payee explains the scenarios for note to payee.

For other fields, to understand where a the information is coming from, you can perform a trace as per this blog below:

  • Analyze the Processing of Outgoing Payment Files from Map Format Data

entry.title: Re: SAP BODS 4.3 Upgrade Issues
entry.content:
There are several components that should be checked:

1. ODBC Driver Configuration (DSN):
Ensure that the ODBC (DSN) used to connect to your repository is properly configured (username/password) If it's missing on the BI server, you‚Äôll need to create it.

2. Registered Repository in CMC:
Verify that the repository registered in the Central Management Console (CMC) is active. It will only be active if it's correctly configured with the appropriate username and password.

3. Job Server Configuration:
Review the job server settings in the "Data Services Server Manager". Make sure the connection is properly established and functioning as expected.

.....
Hope this helps!

entry.title: Re: MB5B - DIfference in the Storage Location stock and V...
entry.content:
Based on your post, the specific issue is movement type 641 (used for stock transfer to subcontractor) is valuated but does not require a storage location. When posted without LGORT (storage location), it updates valuated stock at the plant level. It does NOT update storage location or batch stock, hence MB5B storage location view misses it.

The recommended actions would be

  • Use SE16N or MB51 to list all 641 documents for material LNG in plant 1200. Check if LGORT is blank in MSEG.
  • Review the subcontracting PO setup and ensure storage location is defaulted or manually entered. Consider a validation or enhancement to prevent 641 postings without LGORT. For that, you can explore BAdI MB_DOCUMENT_BADI or enhancement MBCF0002.
  • For plant 1200, reconcile MB5B valuated stock with storage location stock by extracting 641 documents without LGORT. Manually adjusting or reporting the delta.

entry.title: Re: Error when creating the report engine
entry.content:
This issue is caused by a bug in the MANIFEST.MF file inside the rebean.wi.jar
The entry is incorrectly split across two lines:
Bundle-Configurator: com.businessobjects.rebean.wi.impl.config.RebeanC
onfigurator

To fix this, you can manually correct the manifest file:
1. Open the JAR file using a tool like WinRAR.
2. Navigate to MANIFEST.MF
3. Edit the line to ensure it's written on a single line:
Bundle-Configurator: com.businessobjects.rebean.wi.impl.config.RebeanConfigurator

4. Save the changes and update the jar file.

Important: Before making any modifications, create a backup of the original JAR file to avoid potential issues.

....
Hope this helps‚Äîand hopefully, SAP will address it in upcoming patches.

entry.title: Re: Overhead Accounting with Universal Parallel Accounting in SAP S/4HANA 2025
entry.content:
Thank you very much for the post, @Janet_Salmon .
Regarding template allocations there are three phases in which they should be used:
1. Planning process (LTP). The objective is to obtain the activity rates; to do this, we must obtain activity quantities required for the planned production and transfer this to cost centers.
2. Cost estimate. With the activity rates already calculated, we determine the indirect costs using template allocations.
3. Actual cost. At the end of the period, we determine the indirect costs of the manufacturing orders using template allocations.

Points 2 and 3 are resolved in SAP:
2. In the standard cost estimate when you create a costing run the cost center/activity type combinations entered in the template are automatically included.
3. For production orders and process orders you run template allocation at period-close to collect the quantities relevant for allocation using transactions CPTD/CPTA.

But can point 1 be done in SAP using Long Term Planning? (LTP)
Is it possible to collect activity-relevant quantities for planned orders using template allocations? How can be done?

Thanks for your answer,
Kiko

entry.title: Re: Project System - Scheduling
entry.content:
First thing, what relationships have you defined between the Network Activities?

Check the Network graphic to see the Critical Path.  The definition of Critical Path is the float is 0 on an Activity so the Early and Lates Dates are the same.

You need to look at PS Scheduling from 2 viewpoints, WBS Dates and Network Activity Dates.  SAP has almost too much functionality with regards to scheduling.  Since you are using Network Activities then WBS scheduling just follows along with the Network Activity dates.

In your configuration for WBS scheduling make sure you have set "Network Determines Dates" and I use Strict Bottom Up Scheduling.  This makes sure the WBS dates are aligned with the NWA dates.  and subsequently the Project Definition Dates will be determined by the roll up of the WBS Dates which are coming from the NWAs.

With regards to NWA scheduling if you do not have an absolute constraint on a NWA (Must Finish On or Must Start On) then the dates you enter on the Network HEADER determine the starting point for schedule calculation.  It will use either your Start or Finish Date depending on what scheduling you set, either Forward of Backward.  SAP always performs a forward and backward schedule calculation it starts with the direction you specify.

Also look into your NWA scheduling parameters and see if you allow scheduling into the past and by how many days.  I usually set this to the maximum 999 days.

All of these settings come into play when calculating the dates.

entry.title: Re: Error "Native class not defined" generated when deplo...
entry.content:
There is a typo in that note.  The install command is missing the -g argument.  I will let the processor know and get that corrected.  In the meantime, you will need to delete the node_modules folder from your project and reinstall using the following command.

npm i @SAP/mdk-tools -g

You should also delete the SIGNATURE.SMF file as well.  Then try your deploy again and let us know if that fixes the issue.

Thanks,

--Bill

entry.title: SAP BPA Updating API specification deletes all previous Actions
entry.content:
There seems to be some major bugs in the SAP BPA tool. The more I work with it, the more frustrating it is üò§

One of them is if you have an Actions project with some endpoints pointing to a CAP service and if for some reason you update the CAP service with new actions/functions/entities, it deletes all the previous actions within the Actions project and you need to start all over again.

I have a CAP service that exposes an action called myAction1. I then have an Actions Project in SAP Build which consumes the actions exposed by the CAP service via a destination.  So for the first time I am able to add myAction1 to the Actions project

And myAction1 appears fine.

I then add another action in my CAP service called myAction2 and deploy it to BTP.  In SAP Build Actions Project, the new endpoint myAction2 doesn't show up which is fine as it doesn't have the updated specification.

I then click on Update API Specification in the Actions project and it takes me through some steps where it now shows the myAction2 endpoint.

At the end of these steps, it shows me a dialog with an Update button. In the background of the popup, it still shows myAction1 that was added and saved.

When I then click on Update, it shows a popup asking to choose the endpoints and it removes the existing myAction1 entry that was already saved. I choose myAction2 to add.

myAction1 has disappeared and I would have to add it all over again.

There should be a way to update the API specification without the existing actions getting deleted from the project. Can this be fixed or a workaround to this ?

Regards,

Melwyn.

entry.title: Re: LT_FILTER_SELECT_OPTIONS return nothing
entry.content:
I can't tell from the screen shots but when you tested from the gateway client using substringof did it work or not?

Is your service a custom odata service or is this one of the default services?

We have many customers using ABAP backends where the default MDK search using substringof is working.  If substring is not working in your service you can always override the default MDK search that is sent to not send that using substringof.  You would need to determine what searching you want to support then based on what filtering your service can support.

--Bill

entry.title: Modernizing RFC/BAPI-based Integrations for a Clean Core with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In most SAP landscapes, SAP Process Orchestration has long been the trusted bridge between the ERP core and the outside world ‚Äî connecting SAP and non-SAP systems through RFC & BAPI calls, IDocs, and Web Services, and so on. As organizations now move toward SAP S/4HANA and SAP Integration Suite, the migration journey isn‚Äôt just about replacing middleware; it‚Äôs about evolving decades of integration logic into cloud-ready, clean-core-compliant patterns.

Among the many interface types found in SAP PI/PO, RFCs/BAPIs stand out as the most functionally embedded. They provide direct access to business objects within the SAP ERP core ‚Äî for instance, to check material availability, retrieve purchase orders, or update financial postings. This tight coupling, while powerful, also poses modernization challenges, for example by not facilitating easy interoperability with external applications, in today‚Äôs composable enterprise era.

Recognizing this, SAP has expanded the Migration Assessment capability in Integration Suite to not only analyze and migrate integration artifacts, but also to recommend modernization opportunities. With the release of Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for BAPIs in Q3 2025, architects can now automatically identify BAPIs used in legacy PI/PO interfaces and discover modern, SAP-managed API equivalents via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This opens up a structured path for customers to not just migrate their interfaces, but also modernize them for clean core and interoperability.

Note: In Q2 2025, SAP released Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for IDOCs. Now, this feature is extended to BAPIs as well.

This blog dives into what that means in practice ‚Äî exploring three architectural paths for evolving BAPI-based integrations as they move from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite, balancing speed, effort, and alignment with the clean core vision.

A word about ‚ÄúClean Core‚Äù ‚Äì The Guiding Principle for Continuous Transformation

Clean core is not a product ‚Äî it‚Äôs a philosophy. It is a set of guiding principles that help organizations maintain an agile, upgrade-stable, and innovation-ready ERP landscape. By reducing custom code and relying on standardized, lifecycle-managed APIs and extensions, clean core supports continuous transformation without technical debt. The broader paradigm of Clean core, can be approached in 5 different dimensions, with Integration being one of them, as mentioned in the following figure:

Learn more about the Clean Core approach

Three Architectural Paths to Move BAPI-Based Integrations to SAP Integration Suite

When moving your legacy RFC/BAPI-based interfaces from SAP PO to Integration Suite, there are multiple approaches ‚Äî each balancing speed, effort, and modernization depth.

Let‚Äôs look at these three paths:

Approach

Lift and Shift

Clean Core Modernization

Protocol Modernization

What it entails

Continue to use the RFCs/BAPIs as-is and connect them directly from Integration Suite using the RFC adapter.

Replace BAPIs with standard APIs published by SAP, documented in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Replace the RFC connectivity by exposing the same RFC/BAPI as a SOAP Web Service.

Benefits / drawbacks

‚áß Fastest transition with minimal rework

‚áß No revalidation of business logic or functional behaviour

‚á© No interoperability. Opportunity to modernise is not leveraged.

‚áß These APIs are SAP-managed, upgrade-stable, and designed for HANA-optimized data access.

‚áß Facilitates interoperability.

‚á© SOA Manager Z-objects are customer-managed.

Key enablers

Migration Tooling (automated flow conversion from PO ICO to Cloud Integration iflow)

‚üπ Migration Assessment ‚Üí Modernization Recommendations

‚üπ Explore APIs on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Kindly refer following tutorial / blog links:

‚üπ  How easy it is to consume a Function Module as a Web Service

‚üπ  Modernize RFC Receiver Connectivity

Best suited for

‚üπ Interim phases where backend refactoring is not yet possible (e.g., ECC system, not yet on S/4HANA)

‚üπ Projects under strict time constraints where migration speed takes priority

Building a future-ready, interoperable, and clean-core-compliant integration landscape

‚üπ Scenarios where no equivalent SAP standard API exists.

‚üπ Transitional architectures that need interoperability before full modernization.

Tips & considerations

The best time to start your PO modernization was yesterday ‚Äî the next best is today. Early planning prevents ‚Äúlift and shift‚Äù compulsions later on.

‚üπ Requires functional remapping between legacy BAPI fields and API structure

‚üπ Regression testing and business validation needed

 

Now, we will showcase how a BAPI based interface in our SAP PO landscape can be moved to Integration Suite, applying 1) Lift and Shift, and 2) Clean Core modernization approaches (We will not be covering the Protocol Modernization approach in this post, as it is already nicely covered in the blog / tutorials written by my colleagues ‚Äì links to which I have shared in the above table).

Example BAPI-based Interface setup in SAP PO:

Consider the example of Material ATP check interface, which uses BAPI_MATERIAL_AVAILABILITY, to fetch the available stock quantity of a given Material, at a given Plant and Storage location. The BAPI is exposed to consuming application SAP CPQ, via a REST API layer, in our SAP PO system. Following are a few screenshots of the interface setup in PO system, specifically also highlighting the request and response fields.

Migration using Lift and Shift approach:

Here, we illustrate how this interface can be moved to Cloud Integration, using Lift and Shift approach, with the aid of Migration Tooling. As we mentioned in the above table, this approach will retain the RFC adapter as it is, in the automatically generated Cloud Integration iflow artifact.

Note: There are additional pre-requisite steps to connect your PO system to BTP sub-account, through the Cloud connector. Kindly refer this help portal page, for more details. This is an essential step, to be able to do Migration Assessment as well as to migrate interfaces from PO to Cloud Integration, using Migration Tooling.

We launch the Migration Tooling guided wizard, by clicking the Migrate button, from within the package.

At the end of the guided wizard, we see that the integration flow is automatically generated, keeping the technical implementation aspects, exactly as it was in PO system (such as connectivity protocols, message mappings, message schema, etc.)

The iflow is broken into multiple integration processes, for better readability. In this case, the request and response mapping steps are modularised into separate integration processes, which are called from the main integration process.

 

The following screenshot shows a closer view of the main integration process ‚Äì with receiver adapter RFC being used to call S/4HANA system, to fetch the Material ATP information.

Migration using Clean Core Modernization approach:

Next, we will walk you through the Clean core modernization approach, to move our BAPI_MATERIAL_AVAILABILITY based interface to Cloud Integration.

As stated in the beginning of this post, we start with analysing the latest generated Migration Assessment report. If you have run the migration assessment of your PO landscape before SAP released the ‚ÄúClean Core Modernization Recommendations for BAPIs‚Äù feature, kindly re-run the assessment. The new version of the report will have additional worksheets, containing these recommendations.

In the Recommendations sheet, you can see the Possible Modernization Item across each pillar ‚Äì such as Protocol, Security, Clean core, Integration Style, etc.

In the API Recommendations sheet, you can see the equivalent S/4HANA API for the underlying BAPIs used in each of the PO interfaces, that uses BAPI based integration.

Next, we proceed to Business Accelerator hub, to explore the API definition of the recommended API:

This OData API can be adopted in our Cloud Integration iflow or be exposed to other applications via API Management layer, to fetch the Material ATP details. We leave the implementation details to you, to model the orchestration layer, as you deem fit, based on your business scenario.

With this approach, we have modernized a BAPI based integration into a modern one ‚Äì i.e. OData API based, thereby reaping the benefits such as upgrade-stable interface, clean core, interoperability, and so on.

Closing Thoughts

Integration modernization is not just a migration exercise ‚Äî it‚Äôs an opportunity to realign enterprise integration with the clean core vision and build a foundation for continuous transformation & business agility, by taking advantage of the modern, cloud-native features and open protocols offered by SAP Integration Suite.
Every interface we modernize is a building block of a cleaner, more interoperable ERP core. With SAP Integration Suite and the new modernization recommendations, the journey from legacy BAPIs to standard APIs has never been clearer ‚Äî or more achievable.

Related Reading: If you‚Äôre working on IDoc-based integrations, check out my earlier post on how to modernize IDoc to APIs and Events, leveraging the Migration Assessment modernization recommendations for IDOCs.

entry.title: Re: Project System - Scheduling
entry.content:
Hi ladislavpl

When scheduling dates from a network, SAP uses the start and finish dates maintained in the network. It uses the finish date for backward scheduling and the start date for forward scheduling. Therefore, make sure to adjust the network‚Äôs start and finish dates before running the scheduling process.

Regards
Marcio Blos

entry.title: How to update completed inspection lots of current stock if the Inspection profile is updated?
entry.content:
We have an inspection profile to update, but also alot of batched stock that each have their own completed inspection lots to populate CoA.

IF we update the profile, what would be the best way to update the lots of all the current stock to update to the new profile specifications?

The current process requires: Moving the material to type 89. Creating new inspection lots for those 10 batches. Updating all the COA profiles for type 89. Waiting until all this stock has been consumed (hoping it is consumed first). Once done, updating the material and COA profiles again in type 4 to return to the normal process for the next manufactured products. Since the TDS and product specifications are living documents, we need a simpler way to reset the UD and update inspection lots already in stock.

entry.title: Re: Add HTML tracking script to a requisition
entry.content:
Per the request, even if you want to track campaign traffic to ONE requisition only, it is not possible anywhere on the job posting via Recruitment module (not embedded/hidden on the internal nor external description, like I envisioned).

Instead, build code into Career Site Builder, Appearance > Global > JavaScript > Footer

Customize the code to trigger for only a specific Job Posting, based on the ID in the URL. To achieve this, use a JavaScript IF-THEN statement with the tracking code inside where the "Your code here" comment is.  Note this code will also log it in the F12 console:

<script>
// Get the current URL
const currentUrl = window.location.href;
 
// Check if it ends with the specific number
if (currentUrl.includes('123456'))  {
  console.log("URL ends with 123456 ‚Äî running code...");
  // Your code here
}
</script>

entry.title: Re: Creating a BP (Customer Role) and Associating a Company
entry.content:
After resolving this issue, and considering that there were not many responses and I couldn‚Äôt find concrete examples, I am sharing my solution to it.

This solution involved using several BAPIs: BAPI_BUPA_CREATE_FROM_DATA, BAPI_BUPA_ROLE_ADD_2, BUPA_TAX_ADD, BAPI_BUPA_FRG0040_CHANGE, CVI_EI_INBOUND_MAIN and BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT.

Below is an example ABAP code showcasing this implementation:

      DATA:
          ls_central TYPE BAPIBUS1006_CENTRAL,
          ls_central_org TYPE BAPIBUS1006_CENTRAL_ORGAN,
          ls_addressdata TYPE BAPIBUS1006_ADDRESS,
          lv_bpnumber TYPE BAPIBUS1006_HEAD-BPARTNER,
          lt_return TYPE TABLE OF BAPIRET2.

      ls_central-partnertype = 'GE00'. " Geral
      ls_central-searchterm1 = 'Test'.

      ls_central_org-name1 = 'Name'.

      ls_addressdata-standardaddress = 'X'.
      ls_addressdata-c_o_name = 'Test'.
      ls_addressdata-city = 'Lisbon'.
      ls_addressdata-postl_cod1 = '0000-000'.
      ls_addressdata-country = 'PT'.
      ls_addressdata-street = 'Lisbon Street 101'.
      ls_addressdata-langu = 'P'.

      CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUPA_CREATE_FROM_DATA'
        EXPORTING
          partnercategory = '2' " Organization
          centraldata = ls_central
          centraldataorganization = ls_central_org
          addressdata = ls_addressdata
        IMPORTING
          businesspartner = lv_bpnumber
        TABLES
          return = lt_return.

      DATA:
          lv_businesspartner TYPE BAPIBUS1006_HEAD-BPARTNER,
          lv_businesspartnerrole TYPE BAPIBUS1006_BPROLES-PARTNERROLE.

      lv_businesspartner = lv_bpnumber.

      lv_businesspartnerrole = 'ZFLCU0'. " Customer Role

      CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUPA_ROLE_ADD_2'
        EXPORTING
          businesspartner = lv_businesspartner
          businesspartnerrole = lv_businesspartnerrole
        TABLES
          return = lt_return.

      CALL FUNCTION 'BUPA_TAX_ADD'
        EXPORTING
          iv_partner            = lv_businesspartner
          iv_tax_type           = 'PT0'
          iv_tax_number         = 'PT266598820'
          iv_x_save             = 'X'
        TABLES
          ct_return             = lt_return
        EXCEPTIONS
          record_already_exists = 1
          invalid_data          = 2
          foreign_lock          = 3
          OTHERS                = 4.

      DATA:
          ls_datachange TYPE BAPIBUS1006040_SALESCLASS,
          ls_datachangex TYPE BAPIBUS1006040_SALESCLASSX.

      ls_datachange-attribute = '01'.
      ls_datachangex-attribute = 'X'.

      CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_BUPA_FRG0040_CHANGE'
        EXPORTING
          businesspartner = lv_businesspartner
          data = ls_datachange
          datax = ls_datachangex
        TABLES
          return = lt_return.

      DATA:
           lt_i_data TYPE CVIS_EI_EXTERN_T,
           ls_i_data TYPE CVIS_EI_EXTERN,
           ls_company TYPE CMDS_EI_COMPANY,
           wa_partn TYPE BUS_EI_EXTERN,
           wa_partn_hdr TYPE BUS_EI_HEADER,
           ls_return TYPE BAPIRETM.

      SELECT partner_guid INTO @DATA(lv_guid)
        FROM but000
        WHERE partner = @LV_businesspartner.
      ENDSELECT.

      wa_partn_hdr-object_instance-bpartnerguid = lv_guid.
      wa_partn_hdr-object_instance-bpartner = lv_businesspartner.
      wa_partn_hdr-object_task = 'M'. " Modify
      MOVE-CORRESPONDING wa_partn_hdr TO wa_partn-header.
      MOVE-CORRESPONDING wa_partn TO ls_i_data-partner.

      ls_i_data-customer-header-object_instance-kunnr = lv_businesspartner.
      ls_i_data-customer-header-object_task = 'U'. " Update

      ls_company-task = 'I'. " Insert
      ls_company-data_key = '101'. " Company Code

      ls_company-data-akont = '2111100000'.
      ls_company-datax-akont = 'X'.
      APPEND ls_company TO ls_i_data-customer-company_data-company.
      APPEND ls_i_data TO lt_i_data.

      CALL FUNCTION 'CVI_EI_INBOUND_MAIN'
        EXPORTING
          i_data = lt_i_data
        IMPORTING
          e_return = ls_return.

      CALL FUNCTION 'BAPI_TRANSACTION_COMMIT'
        EXPORTING
          wait = abap_true.

This method populates the following tables: BUT000, KNA1, and KNB1.

I would like to thank you for the help provided!

entry.title: Is It RAP or BOPF? Fiori Programming Model Analyzer for S/4HANA
entry.content:
Last week at SAP Inside Track Rome 2025 I had the chance to present a session about a new tool I‚Äôve been working on recently.

The goal of this tool is to support ABAP developers in identifying the programming model behind a given Fiori app, showing useful information such as:

  • What programming model does this app use ‚Äì BOPF or RAP?
  • What‚Äôs the name of the Business Object ?
  • Has the Fiori Elements app been extended with the Flexible Programming Model?
  • For OData V2 apps ‚Äì sometimes the OData name doesn‚Äôt match the SEGW project name: which one is the correct SEGW project?

You can explore the data directly here:
https://alespad.github.io/s4-fiori-model-analyzer/
(Currently available for S/4HANA 2023 FPS01 and FPS03)

The app can also be run locally, and all data files used by the Fiori viewer (in both JSON and CSV formats) are available in the GitHub project under:

https://github.com/alespad/s4-fiori-model-analyzer/tree/main/docs/data

I also added a ‚ÄúCompare‚Äù view, to analyze differences between releases. I plan to include additional S/4HANA versions over time ‚Äî and of course, I‚Äôm really curious to add 2025 soon!

 

Behind the story

How did this idea come up?

At Syscons, we regularly run internal and customer webinars we call ‚ÄúFiori Enablement‚Äù, designed to help experienced ABAP developers modernize their skills and get ready to work on the latest S/4HANA releases (and even BTP-based developments).

Some time ago, @SergioFerrariIt2 suggested a session called ‚ÄúAnatomy of a Fiori App‚Äù. It wasn‚Äôt easy to prepare, since there‚Äôs no official end-to-end documentation on how to ‚Äúdissect‚Äù a Fiori app. The goal was to show how an ABAP developer can look inside a standard app and understand what‚Äôs really happening behind an action button, a navigation, or any specific UI behavior.

To prepare the session, I chose the Fiori App F1048A ‚Äì Process Purchase Requisition, and started documenting each step:

  • Identify the main object: start from the OData service in the Fiori Library, or use Dev Tools (F12) to see which entity is called when pressing ‚ÄúGo‚Äù.
  • Notice that there are three actions in the table ‚Äì but only one action exists in the RAP object. Comparing ADT Preview with the actual Fiori App, there are no @UI actions, and even an extra column appears in the app. That means the app was extended with the Flexible Programming Model. We can download the app and inspect it locally in VS Code.
  • This app, based on a RAP object, also navigates to other apps that use BOPF via specific actions. Which BOPF objects are they? Here, F12 helps only partially ‚Äî we need to go one level deeper to find the true BO names.

Following this process made me realize how useful it would be to have a tool that automatically shows this information, starting from the app list in the Fiori Library.

What's next?

The data still needs some refinement. I‚Äôm currently reviewing all apps marked as ‚ÄúN/A‚Äù to check whether they really have no identifiable programming model, or if some information is simply missing ‚Äî for example, when the main Entity name is not yet properly detected.

The next step will be to publish the ABAP backend logic ‚Äî the engine that, starting from the Fiori Library export (CSV), analyzes each app‚Äôs manifest.json, cross-references it with DDL source codes and Service Definitions, and generates the JSON/CSV outputs.

I plan to make this ABAP part open source as well.
There‚Äôs a lot of AI-based logic involved, and I‚Äôm exploring great open-source tools like abaplint to make the code even cleaner.

This would allow anyone to:

  • Generate their own JSON/CSV data
  • Potentially analyze custom Fiori apps tool and classify their programming models automatically

I‚Äôll keep posting updates about the progress ‚Äî and if you have feedback, suggestions, or ideas, they‚Äôre very welcome!

entry.title: Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels
entry.content:
This blog was authored by Joule Studio Product Managers: Charan Ravikumar and Maria Kondratyeva

 

Setting Up Joule Studio for All Customer Flows and Entitlement Levels

Joule Studio, the latest capability in SAP Build, enables developers to build Joule skills and Joule agents tailored to unique business needs. These capabilities extend Joule copilot, orchestrate cross-functional workflows, and enhance enterprise efficiency. 

As Skill Builder in Joule Studio is General Available, many early adopters and interested teams are asking the same essential question: "How to get Joule Studio?"

Whether you're a business decision-maker assessing impact, a developer organizing your technical landscape, or a partner helping your customer, this post outlines everything you need to know to get started efficiently and cost-effectively.

Before diving into the setup, it's essential to take a moment to review the commercialization details. It is crucial to ensure that you have the correct plans and SKUs in place for building and executing Joule Skills effectively. Understanding these components will set a solid foundation for a successful implementation.

Let's get started!

 

Pre-Requisites for Customers

SAP Build

    • The SAP Build developer license (SKU 8019311) is required to build, test, and deploy your custom Joule Skills.
    • The new unified SAP Build commercial model is now live across all four models: 
      • Subscription 
      • BTPEA - Business Technology Platform Enterprise Agreement (since August 11)
      • PAYG - Pay As You Go (since August 11)
      • CPEA - Cloud Platform Enterprise Agreement (NEW ‚Äì September 17) 

Joule

    • You will need to have Joule (base or higher) - Joule Base (SKU 8019544) or Joule Premium (SKU 8019164) (Includes AI Units)
    • Joule Studio works  with any Joule brownfield license, except Joule for Consultants and Joule for Developers.

Commercial Details

There is no additional cost for orchestration and invocation of custom Joule skills using the current features in Joule Studio. This means you do not need AI Units to run custom Joule Skills in your production environments.

That said, it‚Äôs important to note that while the orchestration and invocation of a custom skill is free, the underlying components used by your custom Joule Skills will still follow their standard commercial models. For example, if your custom Joule skill kicks off a business process automation, the usage of SAP Build Process Automation will still be billed according to the Business Technology Platform Enterprise Agreement pricing structure.

 

Understanding Your Integration Flow: Customer Starting Points and Required Steps

 This table outlines the five primary customer scenarios for integrating SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA  in the future text) capabilities into the Joule Studio environment.  Identify which flow best matches your current setup, whether you‚Äôre starting fresh or have existing SBPA or Joule subscriptions. This will immediately provide you with the exact action steps and critical notes required for a successful connection.

 

Starting Point

Key Action Steps

The customer is setting up both Joule and SBPA from scratch. 

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect Joule and SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The customer already has Joule (Booster provisioned) and now links the existing SBPA (it must be a build-default plan) for Joule Studio.

  • Verify SBPA Prerequisites: Ensure SBPA entitlement/subscription is on the build-default plan (standard is not compatible).
  • Setup SBPA.  
    Setup SBPA Step by Step Video Guide
  • Both Joule and SBPA need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The customer has an existing SBPA (on the correct build-default plan) and now wants to add Joule.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above for Joule. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Connect the new Joule to the existing SBPA by running the Joule Booster 
    Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
  • Finalize trust/security configurations.
  • Verify entitlement/instance setup. 
  • Access Joule Studio.

The customer already has both services (on the correct plan); they just need to be linked for Joule Studio.

  • Check the Prerequisites mentioned above. Verify the assignments.
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 

The customer has both, but SBPA is on the standard plan (requires an upgrade).

  • Upgrade SBPA to the correct plan (build-default).
  • Both Joule and SBPA  need to be on the same Cloud Identity Service. 
  • Update Formation in Joule Global Account:
    • Navigate to System Landscape -> Formations. 
    • Select the existing Integration with Joule formation.
    • Click Include Systems and select the SBPA subaccount.
    • Check Enable Capability Deployment and finalize. 
  • Wait for Formation Status to become Ready. 
  • Verify SBPA Role Collections. (On SBPA Sub Account) 
  • Create Joule Role Collections. (On Joule Sub Account) 
    • joule_extensibility
    • end_user 
 

Some Questions 

  • I don't have SAP Build! What to do? 
       Initial setup of SAP Build
  • Which license do I need to access Joule Studio? 
       SAP Build Default plan 
  • How can I upgrade my SAP Build Standard Plan to Build Default plan? 
       Change Plan
  • I don't have Joule! What do I do?  
       Initial Setup for Joule
  • How do I run Joule Booster? 
       Instructions to Run Booster 

Helpful Resources for Setup and Activation 

  • How to get started with Joule Studio
  • Provisioning Joule Studio 
  • Enabling Joule Studio for existing customers 
  • Step by Step Video Guide for Joule Studio Activation SAP BTP
  • Reference Architecture for Joule Studio 

Expert Insights

  • If your existing SBPA is on a "Standard" plan, you must upgrade it to the "Build Default" plan before attempting to link it with Joule Studio.
  • Reference Architecture 
    In the picture below, Joule and SBPA are configured within the same subaccount. However, they can also be set up in different subaccounts or even across separate global accounts.
    But in case Joule and SBPA are both in different global accounts, this is also possible, but with the same Cloud Identity Service for both accounts.

entry.title: Questions on EBS SAP Public cloud
entry.content:
Hi Experts, 

We are encountering two issues in the Electronic Bank Statement process in SAP Public Cloud:

  1. We are unable to use document type ZR instead of SA.

  2. The system is not clearing entries automatically after uploading the bank statement. One entry posts correctly, but an additional entry is generated that debits and credits the clearing account. As a result, the amount in the main bank account remains uncleared.

entry.title: Re: U.S Tax Reporter Year End 2025
entry.content:
Hi Carlos, Graziela, et al,

I've looked at the Phase I Note (3655969), and somewhat confusingly it shows that for EhP8 systems this is in HRSP F0 (expected) and F1 (not expected)? All the documentation I had seen so far indicated that F0 would be the Base HRSP for this year -- in almost every year it's the HRSP published in October -- so does this mean that we will need to wait for F1, which I think comes out in November, before we can apply the full solution? As usual, there are no manual or independent corrections in the Note -- the HRSP is the only way to get this in the system.

Cheers,
Matt
